docs.abstract: A flurry of federal, state and local action aims to prevent a new housing crisis as the coronavirus pandemic upends the economy.
docs.snippet: A flurry of federal, state and local action aims to prevent a new housing crisis as the coronavirus pandemic upends the economy.
docs.lead_paragraph: The financial shock from the coronavirus pandemic threatens the housing security of millions of Americans, prompting federal, state and local officials — and even judges and the police — to move quickly to ward off foreclosures and evictions.

headline.main: Racing to Head Off Evictions and Foreclosures
headline.print_headline: Officials Act As Millions Risk Losing Their Homes

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)

byline.original: By Conor Dougherty, Matthew Goldstein and Emily Flitter

docs.abstract: Millions of borrowers may be unable to make payments on home loans next week. The mortgage industry says it’s willing to help, but needs the government to back it up.
docs.snippet: Millions of borrowers may be unable to make payments on home loans next week. The mortgage industry says it’s willing to help, but needs the government to back it up.
docs.lead_paragraph: In just days, tens of millions of people across the United States will have to make fresh payments on their mortgages. Their lenders have come up with a plan to help borrowers who can’t pay because of the economic fallout from the coronavirus — and they want the federal government to backstop it.

headline.main: Bankers Pledge Mortgage Help, but Want Billions

byline.original: By Emily Flitter and Matthew Goldstein

docs.abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
docs.snippet: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

headline.main: Trump May Defer Tariff Payments to Help Businesses

docs.abstract: More than 90 percent of the hotels in the U.S. are franchised, and these owners say their business has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic.
docs.snippet: More than 90 percent of the hotels in the U.S. are franchised, and these owners say their business has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic.
docs.lead_paragraph: It all started to fall apart for Vinay Patel about a week ago.

headline.main: Big-Name Hotels Go Empty and Smaller Owners Are Hurt
headline.print_headline: Empty Rooms, and Pockets, Plague Hotel Franchisees

docs.abstract: General Motors says it is aiming to sell a million electric cars and trucks annually by 2025 in the United States and China.
docs.snippet: General Motors says it is aiming to sell a million electric cars and trucks annually by 2025 in the United States and China.
docs.lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich. — Over the last three months, Tesla’s stock price has more than doubled, adding tens of billions of dollars in market value, as investors have concluded that the company is poised to lead the auto industry’s transition to battery-powered vehicles.

headline.main: G.M. Lays Out Ambitions for Electric-Vehicle Lineup to Rival Tesla
headline.print_headline: G.M. Lays Out Ambitions for Its Electric Lineup

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

docs.abstract: As leaders of the world’s wealthiest countries pledged to limit the damage from the coronavirus, they appeared to be operating with limited options.
docs.snippet: As leaders of the world’s wealthiest countries pledged to limit the damage from the coronavirus, they appeared to be operating with limited options.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The people who control money had hoped for so much more. The news that the world’s wealthiest countries were convening to orchestrate a response to the deadly coronavirus outbreak had resonated across economies like the sound of whirring helicopters bringing relief to a disaster zone.

headline.print_headline: Richest Countries Slow to Limit Toll

docs.abstract: A rise in oil prices on Monday suggested traders believe OPEC and Russia will agree on a new cut in oil production this week.
docs.snippet: A rise in oil prices on Monday suggested traders believe OPEC and Russia will agree on a new cut in oil production this week.
docs.lead_paragraph: Rising expectations that some of the world’s major oil producers will agree to production cuts appeared to steady oil prices on Monday.

headline.main: OPEC Tries to Head Off Oil Glut as Coronavirus Saps Demand
headline.print_headline: Promised OPEC Cut Stabilizes Oil Prices

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

docs.abstract: Long-term bond yields are down, meaning investors are worried. Short-term yields are down more, meaning they’re hopeful. Got that?
docs.snippet: Long-term bond yields are down, meaning investors are worried. Short-term yields are down more, meaning they’re hopeful. Got that?
docs.lead_paragraph: Bond yields fell to new lows on Monday. Is that good news or bad?

headline.main: What the Bond Market Is Saying About Investors’ Hopes
headline.print_headline: Hope, Fear and an Appetite for Bonds

docs.abstract: The drop in stocks and bond yields suggests investors think the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cut won’t contain the economic impact of the coronavirus.
docs.snippet: The drop in stocks and bond yields suggests investors think the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cut won’t contain the economic impact of the coronavirus.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve delivered the emergency rate cut investors had been clamoring for at 10 a.m. on Tuesday. The market rally that followed lasted about 15 minutes.

headline.main: Stocks Tumble After the Fed Cuts Rates

docs.abstract: A Consumer Financial Protection Bureau official who was forced out over racist comments promised “political” oversight of regulatory actions, according to a House report.
docs.snippet: A Consumer Financial Protection Bureau official who was forced out over racist comments promised “political” oversight of regulatory actions, according to a House report.
docs.lead_paragraph: Even after regulators fined Wells Fargo $1 billion in 2018 for misdeeds including creating fake accounts in its customers’ names, the bank was facing a slew of other investigations.

headline.main: Wells Fargo Was Promised Soft Handling by Trump Appointee, Democrats Say
headline.print_headline: Democrats Say Trump Appointee Reassured Wells Fargo of Soft Touch
